content.body: nessy: yt?
starting to wake up...
you wouldn't happen to be in the bay area in the near future by any chance would you?
so, yes :)
nothing planned, no
why?
k
i'm starting to look at this subtitles stuff
if you were around i would have suggested lunch so i could get a brain dump
but no worries
i can read also :-)
I've got  to reply to your request and to henry's proposal etc
got lots to do - was just swamped with other stuff this week
(last week, really)
but shoot any questions you have
i've 192 e-mails to read through on the subject (mostly to whatwg; most of the public-html-a11y ones i read as they passed and didn't save)
so i'm sure i'll have questions :-)
best intro is probably http://blog.gingertech.net/2010/04/11/introducing-media-accessibilit-into-html5-media/
gives a background
most discussions on whatwg were about the caption format - ppl don't like DFXP/TTML
so mostly about developing a new format (microformats story all over?)
cool, will read
won't go well with the a11y ppl, but I don't really care what format we use - I think it will be many over time
yeah if we can avoid inventing yet another format that would certainly be good
are you starting to dig into it now?
yeah
bummer - I wanted to give you a list of samples and use cases
will try and get to that today then
oh it'll take me a while i'm sure
no rush
at this point i'm mostly just trying to ground my sense of what use cases are real and what are hypothetical
by looking at what people actually do with subtitles
for example i thought that there was a need to handle individual words being emphasised, but i've yet to find a single example of that in the real world
though i have found two examples of ruby!
i can't say i was ultra-pleased by that, given how ruby is like 10 times harder to deal with than italics :-P
most styled captions are commercial stuff
I'll see if I can find you some examples
that would be awesome
with the use cases - are you ok if I take some screenshots of commercial stuff that may not be generally accessible, but a good example?
yeah totally
Hixie: Dragon Age: Origins has individual words emphasized (in bold), if video games count as examples :)
daedb: sure, take screenshots and upload them to the wiki page :-)
I'll try to remember that next time I see it (or see if Google can find a relevant screenshot)... it has italics too, btw, for character actions (like sighing) :p
about http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=7688
what's POLA?
something of least something?

i've been playing Bad Company 2 too much. I just got spam about some sort of digital camera and the subject line mentioned 5x optical zoom and my brain instantly junked the e-mail on the basis that anything lower than 12x wasn't worth looking at
principle of least astonishment
Hixie: can I also add examples of other time-aligned text to that wiki page?
sure
e.g. chapter markers, linguistic annotation
ok, cool
and: yes, textual audio descriptions are just text with time markers
doublec: thanks
and an honorable mention to Hixie for "something of least something"
Hixie: are you sure the whatwg wiki lets me upload images?
I can't find a means and get the feeling that it's disabled in the mediawiki setup
also, http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Special:ListFiles is empty
nessy: oh you'll have to upload them elsewhere first
ah I see ...
nessy: if you need somewhere to upload them use http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/cgi/uploader/uploader
password is w643kJ6Gv43q3
ah, cool, thanks!
Hixie: good reading - http://main.wgbh.org/wgbh/pages/mag/services/captioning/faq/sugg-styles-conv-faq.html ;-)
I think I'm finding it hard to provide an example of musical notes in captions, since all online systems failed to render musical notes
I keep coming across ppl complaining about it ;-)
it's kinda ironic!
yay, found one!
Hixie: you'd enjoy watching http://svg-wow.org/audio/animated-lyrics.html
annevk: is Daniel around?
sitting next to me
he's also on skype
I just told him about it, seems he's ok
great
could discuss it more over lunch
yep
Hixie: yt?
so TTML does not have ruby support it seems
already falls short of catering to in the wild use of captioning
while being fricking complex
genius
is ruby actually used for captioning in the wild?
http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/Timed_tracks#Ruby
which side of 80/20 inside locales that use ruby for anything at all?
it seems that in Japanese it would be required as otherwise meaning would be ambigious
that is some crazy exmples
*examples
the page is fascinating
well, at least the most complex cases aren't for accessibility
more like gratuitous "just because we can" for translation or karaoke
(I don't mean ruby here. I mean stuff on the page in general)
a lot of the plain text translations look very ugly cmpared to what we get here on tv. and I thought what we have wasn't pretty
ruby annotations are used quite commonly in Japanese subtitles for films and TV programs and such (not just for karaoke or whatever other edge cases)
ok. seems like a FAIL for TTML then
yeah
a lot of the other Japanese caption examples there are not things I at least typically see in normal use
what we get is pretty readable comapred to many of the Latin examples: http://hsivonen.iki.fi/screen/subtitles.jpg
interesting that that uses stroking
is CNN not an example of somewhat complex inline formatting btw?
what is required to support ruby?
ruby markup
goes google
and some CSS styling if you want to place it elsewhere prolly
i18n is so fascinating!
kind of weird the i18n group hasn't catched that with TTML
maybe they don't consider it a requirement
I'm not sure TTML is even properly finalised yet
it's in CR
which means it passed Last Call review
so there is a <ruby> tag in HTML?
yeah
cool - I didn't follow those discussions
http://www.whatwg.org/html#the-ruby-element
MikeSmith: btw did you change the bugzilla mail setup for public-html?
MikeSmith: subtitles ha used white text with black outline for decades over here.
nessy: i'm removing the cnn example because it doesn't seem to be synchronised with the video -- let me know if it is in fact synchronised
s/ha/have/
let me check
do you have any more info on the other ticker example?
is it just reproducing the subtitle below the video?
or is it something else?
oh, that was the one under ticker text?
isn't ticker by definition something else?
it is
the TV example (CNN) I wanted to use as an example how it shows on TV
but it comes with the video and should supposedly be exposed in some way...
but if you only want current web examples, that's fine
othermaciej: yeah, I set the user prefs on the public-html⊙wo bugzilla account to disable all e-mail for the account
so the one that is currently under "ticker text" has both, captions AND ticker text
annevk: <marquee>
i'm just looking for timed tracks, doesn't have to be web-only -- in fact, non-web is more interesting
but the cnn tickers seem to just be a continuous unsynchronised stream of information that happens to be overlaid, you wouldn't want to use the same mechanism for those as for subtitles
hsivonen, that means you need to deploy different video streams
you will notice underneath the video a line of "NOW: Roubini: new regulations...."
MikeSmith: thanks!
that is the ticker text
nessy: right but that's the same as the subtitle
just by chance
nessy: is there somewhere i can experiment with that example in the wild?
i don't really understand what it is showing
also, I am not sure if that is actually a subtitle or "burnt-in" text
there are multiple javascript libraries for doing ticker text
I wouldn't count newscast title of the story as a subtitle
let me see if I can track that one down
just like I wouldn't count mivie titles
hsivonen I don't think that's what that is - it's just intermediate
hmm
it looks like someone finished the mass move
that or bugzilla lied to me about the 235 bugs left
the chapter stuff is interesting... wonder what to conclude from it
there's such a wide variety of ways it is exposed that it might make more sense to just support it in the sense of exposing the data in the API but not doing anything with it otherwise
nessy: ok. I wouldn't count the cable news summary of the last couple of minutes, either
yeah, I was wondering about the chapters
if they are given inside the file, you will only get them successively normally
but for external tracks it is easy to grab them all in one go and display e.g. as a bar at the bottom to click directly to
well certainly we shouldn't disallow the UA from showing UI for them, yeah
annotations also seem like something we should probably leave to sites to figure out, giving them just an API so they don't have to do the timing themselves
basically let them give us a file with the annotation data then have them hook into notifications for when to render each one
wouldn't they handle the file as well then?
otherwise you might as well add time data to the file format...
fwiw, the reason why I wouldn't count titles and summary of the past couple of minutes is that they are customarily considered to be under the rule of the art department of the show
Hixie, for ticker text I am thinking of something like at http://www.scriptocean.com/dticker.html with time markers synchronised to the video
does anyone do that?
so even if we had an elaborate mechanism for them, chances are that the art dept would still want to have full control
and treat them as part of the image
i mean, as hsivonen says, that kind of thing would just be a title in most cases and so burnt in
why is http://dev.w3.org/html5/core/ not a 410 Gone?
and they are data on their own right as opposed to being a synchronized alternative of other data
Hixie: are you referring to me?
nessy: you and hsivonen yeah
http://www.theopensourcery.com/keepopen/?p=2205 points to it
no, the text is not normally burnt in - only on TV
Hixie: to me, that kind of thing seems like something you'd put on the surrounding HTML page
it is an example of text that comes in at a certain time and leaves at a different
Hixie: not logically part of the video
zcorpan, you could commit a Redirect 410 /html5/core/ .htaccess line I suppose
possibly - but then there are definitely times when ticker text is synchronised to the video
hsivonen: it's something i'd expect to see if i uploaded the video to my ipod or played it to my tv, so i'd expect it as part of the video data.
zcorpan, not entirely sure if Redirect was part of the syntax, but I thought it was
annevk: oh right i have cvs access
nessy: would you agree that movie credits are text that comes in at a certain time and leaves at a different time but should be burnt in?
Hixie: in that case, I'd treat it as nice to have but not as a core requirement for the Web
it has very similar properties to captions and subtitles, which is why I think we can have a generic interface to deal with all of them
Hixie: uploading to iPod is not part of the Web mindset
annevk: actually i don't have access to dev.w3.org
movie credits are part of the video production process, therefore burnt in
Hixie: you are supposed to navigate to the original page using Mobile Safari on iPod Touch
hsivonen: it's open content, i should be able to do whatever i like with it
hsivonen: screw that :-P
hsivonen: it's video, i want to treat it as video.
Hixie: depends on what kind of rathole of requirements come with your wishes
nessy: i would expect the kind of thing i see at
well, all external but linked text is either closer or less closely related to the video
nessy: ... http://www.scriptocean.com/dticker.html to be part of the video production process also
but they are all synchronised to it, so they can all be treated the same way
no, ticker text is not part of the video production process - it is created by the publisher normally, not by the producer
well the only time i've ever seen such ticker text is in news shows, where it's definitely part of the production
but if there are other examples i'm certainly eager to have my eyes opened :-)
just because the producer and publisher are the same ;)
I've seen movies on TV with ticker text that is definitely not created by the production of the movie
but it's synchronised with the movie?
e.g. when 9-11 happened, there was plenty of ticker text running over the bottom of a movie
sure but that isn't timed text
it's just a ticker overlay
has nothing to do with the video
roughly synchronised in that case only - synchronised between specific larger sections
zcorpan, done
as I said: text that runs in parallel with video or audio can be more or less tightly related to the video content
that changes nothing in the fact that it is running in parallel to the video
zcorpan, lets see if we get complaints o_O
nice
I do see your point about the difference between a newscast and move examples though, with the newscast the semantic link is stronger

nessy: semantically, it is the difference between something that runs as part of a <video> element, and something that runs as part of wholy unrelated javascript with wholy unrelated <div>s or <canvas> or ARIA live regions or whatnot, which just happens, because of some CSS, to be rendered over the video
nessy: that's a huge difference
nessy: since we're talking about what <video> should provide
is "synchronized with the video but over the top of it" distinct from "synchronized with the video but not on top of it?"
othermaciej: not especially, no
othermaciej: i mean, the former might be handled natively while the latter would likely need JS support, but that's all
is time-based relationship to what the video is currently showing the key semantic relation?
I guess the question is: will it be going along its own timeline or along the timeline of the video
othermaciej: they both would need to be expressed in some timed track format
nessy: right
even if it goes along its own timeline for most of it, there is definitely a link at some point
I'm thinking about the ever-popular "video of presentation with synchronized HTML slideshow below" example
you won't have a ticker text on a video that starts ticking along without the video playing
nessy: not for the 9/11 subtitles. they would have shown those subtitles irrespective of what movie was showing.
not if the video was paused
well there's no way to pause it
since it's all burnt in in that case
I'm talking about having a video like a youtube video on a site
TV is different
if youtube had breaking-news tickers, they wouldn't pause when you pause the video.
if it's burnt-in it's none of our business anyway
burnt-in subtitles tell us what people need on the web
it's entirely our business
it's what i'm using to evaluate the proposals :-)
if I go to a youtube page and the video sits there paused, I don't think I would expect the ticker text to be running
yes, TV gets you some way there, but we have a lot more flexibility on the Web ;)
YouTube has time-synchronized popover ads
but those don't change or go away, they just appear at a certain time
Hixie: I found out something interesting about ruby in Korean
I think we need to offer all that TV can do, but more :)
They’re kind of phasing kanji/hanzi out, and current usage is to have the hangul first, followed inline by the kanji in parentheses, so basically the opposite of the default display…
nessy: i don't, fwiw :-) i think we should offer a small set of functionality in v1, and see what people feel they are truly lacking. baby steps and all.
that's fair enough
ruby associates rt with preceding non-rt ruby base text, and CSS3 Ruby doesn’t have this ruby-position, so currently impossible
we don't have to do ticker text in the first version
i'm trying to find a web page that has tickers and video
I can, however, see a need
but my network is acting poorly
boblet, CSS3 Ruby is somewhat obsolete as it is though and will be updated with HTML5 in mind
I found it difficult to find a video on the Web with ticker text actually, which is why that example came up
but let me look a bit more
boblet: fwiw, "kanji/hanzi", "hangul", and "kanji" are all greek to me. :-)
boblet: what does it mean in terms of html?
annevk: yeah, I read some of www-style on it. Interesting that the Korean usage is outside of CSS3 Ruby tho
for the craziest use of text with video ever got to http://www.masternewmedia.org/video_internet_television/video-annotation/online-video-annotation-takes-a-giant-leap-20070405.htm
Hixie: :)
I can find an example of almost anything you can think of on that page
boblet, if it's inline you don't need ruby markup though
boblet, you can just use normal typography :)
"normal" to be i18n-correct
Hixie: normally <ruby>base text <rt>ruby text</rt></ruby> to give ruby text above in supporting browsers or after in non-supporting browsers (default)
annevk: but that wouldn’t be *semantic* :P hehe
kanji and hanzi are the japanese and chinese names respecitvely for chinese ideographs
hangul is the korean alphabet
boblet, semantics are overrated
Hixie: current Korean usage is ruby text inline *before* base text, but old CSS3 ruby-position has every side but before
annevk: not to pedants
boblet, sure, but they're wrong
boblet, most of HTML is focused on pragmatism, not pure semantics
Hixie: also because no <rb> anymore source order is fixed it’s not possible to rearrange in source
ok, I found the Roubini example - I think what I thought was ticker text is actually an unrelated title div
(note that I’m not suggesting this is important enough to warrant <rb> as Korean is moving away from using anything that needs ruby)
Hixie: I don't mind about dropping ticker text from time-aligned text types and waiting till the market catches up
annevk: heh
boblet: wait so koreans write <ruby><rt>ruby text</rt>base text</ruby> and it works in IE?
nessy: k
nessy: i'll remove that section for now
Hixie: after all, I waited for 10 years for the Web to catch up with my ideas of how hyperlinked video and captions should be done ;)
ok

http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/html/raw-file/tip/tests/submission/Microsoft/interface/anchor_href.htm - the framework seems to need unnecessary boilerplate and has the arguments backwards in assertEquals (compared to how i'd order them)
Hixie: I have yet to see a code example or make a test case
thinks there is a business idea in video ticker text offerings… ;)
boblet: then i don't understand what you mean by "ruby text inline *before* base text"
Hixie: based on display of an image I was sent demonstrating current usage
zcorpan: I like the WebKit framework for script tests a *lot* better
boblet: can you upload it so i can see?
both the output and the code there are icky
wip ;-)
I think boblet is saying they write "blah (blah)"
and therefore don't need ruby at all, but since it's called ruby pedants want to use ruby markup?
but the (blah) is what the blah would be in Japanese
haha, I just found a better example for ticker text, but also from Yahoo, see http://media.rgemonitor.com/images/blogs/10082008tt.jpg
annevk: there are some benefits in having reading semantically marked up you know. surely you’ve seen a few kanji by now? :P
and this: http://www.freewaregenius.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/11/Free-Stocks-Ticker-Screenshot.jpg
anyway - can all be done with javascript of course, so I don't really mind
Hixie: http://oli-studio.com/temp/ruby-korean.jpg
nessy: the second one doesn't even have a video!
ah, you're right!
boblet: ah well i'm happy to say that you can do that in text/plain
nessy: i think that pretty much guarantees that i'm right that it's not linked to the video :-P
top line shows Japanese-style ruby, with ruby text above base text
oh, there are plenty of tickers that go without a video, that's for sure
othermaciej: I think I got something slightly over 400 bug emails - was that the total number of bugs that you were changing (including the 235)?
Philip`: 493
but if no callbacks are required and all that is required is to start the thing on video playback and to stop it on video pause/end, then indeed the time-alignment is minimal

Hixie: true, but as mentioned there are linguistic benefits of indicating the phonetics of something. also if all we’re worried about with ruby is placement above it’s far more a presentational element than I thought :)
nessy: i'm not even convinced there's that -- i
nessy: ...i've yet to see a video with a ticker that isn't burnt in but that pauses when you pause the video
yeah, I saw :)
boblet, ruby markup makes sense for the top line in http://oli-studio.com/temp/ruby-korean.jpg but is not needed at all for the other lines
on the Web the tickers aren't bunt in, but they also may not stop, as you are saying, so same effect
boblet, I fully support ruby markup for examples similar to the top line (as used in Japan)
boblet: that Korean markup case you mentioned is interesting (the logogram in parens after the phonetic reading, instead of the other way around)
hey Mike
boblet: if all you want to do is render <ruby>bbb<rt>aaa</rt></ruby> as aaabbb then the answer is to use CSS (not ruby CSS, just regular CSS)
boblet: though CSS doesn't yet support rendering things out of order like that, it's something the wg intends to provide eventually
nessy: well if they don't stop with the video, they're definitely not timed tracks
anyway
yeah, fair enough
Hixie: based on CSS3 Ruby module it seemed like that presentation slipped through the cracks. I’ll try to email about it tho, so hopefully it can be included in CSS3 Ruby mark 2
boblet: it shouldn't be in the CSS ruby module
boblet: it's not ruby presentation
boblet: it's just regular inline rendering but with out of order flow
Hixie: then ruby-position: after also shouldn’t be there huh. ok that makes sense
which module would that end up in?
what does 'ruby-position: after' do?
no idea what module it should be in... TabAtkins or annevk might know
Hixie: according to that spec same rendering as non-supporting browser
that seems like a waste of time then, they could have just used display:inline :-)
Hixie: so you read my article after all ;)
j/k, although I mentioned it in there
MikeSmith: thanks for the feedback

Random, probably rather obvious, point; for sufficiently simple captions it's not clear to me that I want them overlayed on the video in the same way that they are on the TV. For fullscreen it makes sense but if I am watching something that only takes up 50% of my screen height I might want the subtitles to sit under the video
zcorpan: It is not clear to me that there is a "natural" order for the arguments of assertEquals
assertEquals(1+1, 2);
assertEquals(2, 1+1);
The first sounds more natural to me
jgraham: i often omit message, so from that point of view at least message should be last
zcorpan: I tend to agree but I guess the idea here is that the message is mandatory
Philip`: agree, (test, expectation) seems like the natural order
I'm not sure I agree
If you wrote it like assert(1+1 == 2) I would agree
But assert equals 2, 1+1 also makes sense
Not typical english word order but logical
Balloons exploading are kinda loud.
gsnedders: happy birthday
zcorpan: thanks.

zcorpan: In any case it's not clear to me that having lots of debates about the precise best format for testsuites is a good use of time. If microsoft are happy to write tests in this format, that is fine
They should make vacuum-filled balloons
Vacuum is much lighter than helium or even hydrogen, and the balloons could never explode
Although I can't say that I would be inclined to use it myself
(the only other option seems to be adopting some preferred framework in which case it is worthwhile to debate all the specifics)
Which I guess is a point worth rasing on the list
jgraham: sure
jgraham: imagine if you also had assertFalse(), assertTrue(), assertThrowsException()
in each case you would want the test expression as the first parameter I think
so for consistency, assertEquals should also have it first, and the expectation second
my 2c anyway
othermaciej: assertThrows should take some object to indicate the expected type and properties of the exception
So that isn't an obvious counter-example
jgraham: it also needs to take a string to eval instead of an expression to do anything useful
Isn't it better to pass a function(){} to call than a string to eval?
this is what WebKit's script tests look like: http://trac.webkit.org/export/57879/trunk/LayoutTests/fast/dom/HTMLAnchorElement/set-href-attribute-hash.html
othermaciej: I would pass a function
and view the linked script-tests/set-href-attribute-hash.js to see what the actual test scripts look like
has written an assertThrows with the signature assertThrows(expectedException, callable, message)
I think both the output and the source are more readable than Microsoft's format
(or whoever came up with that)
we use strings for both the test expression and the expectation
that way shouldBe (our version of assertEquals) can catch exceptions
so it can report unexpected throw instead of making the rest of the test bomb out
otherwise you have to either surround every test assertion with try/catch, or pass everything as closures
I don't like using strings; making everything rely on eval can have surprising results
in practice it hasn't caused a problem
other than people getting confused about the need to double-quote actual strings
anyway, strings are not the main point
my point was (a) readable output; (b) readable test script
I think quoting hell plus the lack of syntax highlighting for the test code is enough to put me off
could easily convert the system to use all closures
here is one with examples of more of the types of assertions: http://trac.webkit.org/export/57879/trunk/LayoutTests/fast/js/regexp-compile.html

We have a whole bunch of javascript tests that use assertEquals(expected, actual, [message]) type syntax, use try/catch on the backend to handle failures and uses closures for cases where the test is expected to throw
It has worked pretty well
and the corresponding JS source: http://trac.webkit.org/export/57879/trunk/LayoutTests/fast/js/script-tests/regexp-compile.js
(nothing that I can link to sadly)
anyway, say what you will about the details of the assert function parameters, I think our output is the most useful I have seen for script tests
the color makes it easy to spot failures at a glance, it copies to plain text well, it doesn't have pointless tables, etc
However, I think the main difficulty with DOM tests (rather than pure ECMAScript tests) is dealing with async results\
e.g. if you want to test that some event is fired when it ought to be
another reason to use strings is to include the test expression in the test output
so you don't have to say what ou tested a second time
that's definitely a problem with *some* DOM tests
not with the attributes of the <a> element though
Well no
But in general, if you want a framework that deals well with testing DOM, it has to test async stuff well
That is the problem that I don't feel I have ever found a good solution to
we use ad hoc methods
(A good general solution rather than just making it up for each specific case)
the most annoying is if you want to test that some async event fires eventually, and one possible bug is that it never fires
then you kinda have to add an arbitrary timeout, unless you know of a later event that will likely fire even in the bug case
Yeah, but that's a pretty typical case
othermaciej: But the problem with outputting the JS source is that doing it as the WebKit tests do relying upon eval seems bad
we end up just relying on the fact that our test framework times out eventually
So it sucks if you have to reinvent the wheel every single time
gsnedders: I hate eval as much as the next guy, but the string thing works really well in this case - too bad JS doesn't have macros
othermaciej: If you write tests with one test per function, you can toString the function to get the text of the test
i now have a default timeout of 2s (many tests depend on network so need quite a long timeout) and require an explicit end() when the test is done in my framework
it's not quite as simple
it works pretty well for async tests
othermaciej: Until you come across cases where you have bugs and eval has bugs the normal codepath doesn't (or vice-versa)
does assertEqual(1+1, 2, "1+1", "2"); in order to be able to output the JS source without relying on eval
jgraham: true, and then you are just trading off the oddities of eval and the awkwardness of quoting for the oddities of code in a function and the awkwardness of saying function() { } all the time
Philip`: I think repeating yourself is a worse programming sin than eval
...with an ugly custom preprocessor language that converts "@assert 1+1 == 2;" into that syntax automatically
so that I don't have to repeat anything :-)
using a preprocessor is cheating :-)
othermaciej: But functions work better in the case of JITing compilers that compile whole functions at once, as then you can just loop the function
It's true that tests-in-a-function can have problems if you want to test something that specifically depends on global scope
does assertEquals(1+1, 2, "1+1") or just assertEquals(1+1, 2)
still wonders what y'all think of the output format, as opposed to the use of eval
These problems are perhaps more pronounced if you are trying to test the ECMAScript engine itself rather than the DOM
The output format is I don't think an issue, and is really just a bikeshed :)
http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/html/raw-file/tip/tests/submission/Microsoft/interface/anchor_href.htm is really ugly
othermaciej: It's pretty nice. Not quite to die for though ;)
and looks like it would be hard to spot failures
tables with double borders on everything, srsly
Yes, I would turn off the table borders and use some colour there
I don't get why it's a table at all
I also can't tell what it's actually testing from reading
's output is a <pre> which says "PASS" if it passed, or "FAIL" followed by the failing messages if it failed
since the descriptions are arbitrary strings and don't show the code it ran
readable test output makes it much easier for implementors to look at the test and fix their implementations accordingly
which is why I think it's important, more so than the details of how test assertions are coded
othermaciej: I need to read the source code in either case to be confident I know what is going on
which is why it helps for the source to be readable too, which is why I dislike the giant try/catch blocks, and the fact that it's hard to map the table output to the test assertions in the source
Giant try/catch blocks are unnecessary
You should be able to do function testAddition() {assertEquals(2, 1+1)}

I hypothesize that video games have more markup in subtitles because they're really targeted at everyone, not just the hard-of-hearing.  In many games, not all lines are even voice-acted, so subtitles have to be on.  In other cases the speaker might be far away or drowned out by loud noises, since dialog isn't always fully scripted.

Also, they're always from scripts, so you can copy italics from the scripts if applicable.  In unscripted videos, or videos that follow a loose script, there's no transcript to tell you definitively whether something should be italicized or bolded or such.

I don't think 3D video games are good examples to base HTML5 video stuff on, except if it's an actual video cutscene rather than an in-game dialog (and actual video cutscenes are rare these days in games).
notes that Portal (and presumably HL2 too?) has both subtitles (for everyone) and closed captions (for hard-of-hearing)
(where the latter includes textual alternatives to sound effects)

browser geeks, may I ask for some help w/ rdfa idioms?
in rdfa/xhtml it is ok to put in the of a doc...
...if such a block of markup found its way out of the xhtml universe and into html5 or pre-html5 html doc header, ... does anyone know of ugly side-effects of putting object/span there?
danbri: The <object> would force an implicit </head><body> in most (all?) browsers
(It seems pretty bogus that HTML4 (hence XHTML) allows <object> in <head>, since it doesn't work like that)
so if this is done, it should be the last section of <head> at least?
It can't end up in head at all in HTML5/real text/html browsers
well this design is for the xhtml flavour, but it would be nice if it was non-destructive if it leaked elsewhere
what would the practical consequences be?
(hopefully the html/rdfa wg will come up with some microdata/rdfa hybrid in future and i won't have to be asking such things next year...)
danbri: Play around with http://livedom.validator.nu/?%3C!DOCTYPE%20html%3E%0A%3Chead%3E%0A%3Cobject%3E%3C%2Fobject%3E

Basically the practical consequences wouldbe that anything that expected the object to end up in head would break and there would be a high chance of collateral damage from things moving out of head that shouldn't
so only rdfa parsers would be looking for it in head...
The practical consequences would be that HTML5 parser developers would curse you for exploiting misfeatures in the HTML4 DTD
...and if the <object> block was the last thing in </head> then nothing else would be bumped into body...
and it would abort in pure streaming HTML5 parsers
when it hits the explicit <body> later
A non-legacy timed text format that doesn't support ruby... heh
danbri: <head><link etc><object></object><body foo> would (in non-streaming parsers) give the same DOM as <head><link etc></head><body foo><object></object> so that should indeed work
and spans inside the object would survive? page display and function generally ok in currently deployed browser?
danbri: As far as I'm aware, yes
although it looks like IE6 doesn't put the <object> element in the DOM at all
and puts the <span> element as a child of the <head>
Oh, and then it crashes
note that putting <object> in <head> is non-conforming in XHTML5 and HTML5
thanks guys
so what's this about 'would abort'? I thought html5 parsers were softer, gentler more accepting creatures...
In slightly rare cases, like if you want SAX output without potentially-unlimited internal buffering in the parser, there are some errors you can't correctly recover from
e.g. <body foo><body bar> (which should be equivalent to <body foo bar> but it's too late if you emit the body element after reading the first tag)
which (unless I'm mistaken) is what happens when you put non-head content inside a <head> (so it emits an implicit body element) and then have a body tag later
yeah, if you have a streaming parser (unusual for web browsers, but probably not unusual for rdfa processors) then that would likely cause an abort
unless the streaming processor basically buffers everything
but then it's not really streaming
ok well it seems the folk i'm helping are gonna stick with 'meta tags' for now
